Myth #5: SNAP completely covers the costs of food for recipients

Fact: SNAP was built to supplement household food costs, not completely cover them. In fact, prior to the Thrifty Food Plan update, SNAP did not cover the cost of a low-income meal in 96% of U.S. counties. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-xjAbwXMAIUMwt.jpg

Myth #4: SNAP disincentivizes work

Fact: A majority of SNAP recipients who can work, do work. More than 80% of SNAP households work in the year before or the year after receiving SNAP. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-xi8N_WUAES5nc.jpg

Myth #3: SNAP is rife with fraud

Fact: SNAP fraud is exceedingly rare. According to the Congressional Research Service, less than .01% of 
benefits have been mistakenly issued due to recipient fraud. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-xizHjXEAM_67G.jpg

Myth #2: Charities can replace the help SNAP provides

Fact: While food banks provide meals for food-insecure communities, SNAP is far more wide-reaching and efficient. SNAP delivers nine times more food to people than all the food banks in the country. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-xit4pXoAUSOID.jpg

Myth #1: SNAP drains the economy

Fact: For every dollar utilized by a SNAP recipient, $1.79 is infused into their local economy. Additionally, SNAP lowers healthcare costs by nearly $1,400 per person. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-xipqRWUAEPuOu.jpg

On October 1st, SNAP benefits will increase by 21% permanently. I know there are many misconceptions about the program. Here are five common myths and facts about SNAP benefits you should know. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-xfclbWEAcMjDZ.jpg

We‚Äôre grateful to be able to tell these stories, but there are still Americans and Afghan partners trapped in Afghanistan. We will continue to work around the clock to help all of them reach safety.

A third family got held up by the Taliban on the way to the airport. When someone tried to run through the checkpoint, the Taliban began firing. One of the family members was trampled. Thankfully, the family finally made it out of Afghanistan and back to Texas.

Another family had to overcome Taliban checkpoints, a firefight, and a stampede. In desperate need of medical attention, these Americans finally made it past the Taliban and into the airport and safety.

A Houston family was visiting relatives in Afghanistan when the Taliban seized Kabul. One of the family members was well known to the Taliban for the support provided to the United States, and as a result the entire family was in danger. They are now safely out of Afghanistan.

Their stories are powerful and important to share.

For their safety and for the safety of those still trying to get out, we‚Äôre not sharing personal info or details about how specifically they escaped.

In the last several weeks, networks of NGOs, private citizens, & veterans have worked with Congressional offices to try to evacuate Americans & Afghans who worked with us from Afghanistan.

Today, I want to share just a few stories of the over 1,000 people our team has assisted.

Honored to join my colleagues in urging the @DeptVetAffairs to quickly develop & carry out an outreach plan for veterans of Afghanistan & the GWOT. QUOTE TWEET with your story of how these policies would help your family or business, so we can keep up the pressure up. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-yw3hHVgAEaAvH.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-yw32TVQAU-8Ed.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-yw4YmVUAASf1I.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-yw4lsVUAISMqL.png

We're demanding an investment in child care that 1) extends through elementary school, 2) caps costs at 7% of income, 3) avoids unnecessary bureaucracy by administering aid through providers, 4) doesn't bog families down in paperwork, and 5) rebuilds the child care industry.

We all have an interest in our economy‚Äôs future. That means we all have an interest in child care. Right now, Congressional committees are working on child care policy. @RepSherrill and I led 100+ of our colleagues in laying out what an effective child care investment needs.

The child care crisis is a crisis of productivity. It's economic quicksand that's miring multiple generations: older folks who provide unpaid child care to grandchildren, parents who exit the workforce, and kids who fall behind because their families can't afford quality care.

These realities are a big problem for our economy. Businesses can't recruit because child care eats up nearly all entry-level pay. Women are stalled out in parity in achieving leadership positions. Jobs during non-traditional hours are dominated by men.

Facts:
1‚É£ In most states, child care costs more than in-state college tuition.
2‚É£ Child care costs have risen 1000% in recent years‚Äîfaster than housing and health care.
3‚É£ Women got 12% of new jobs last month. At this rate, it‚Äôll take 9 years to return to pre-pandemic employment.

If you want a strong and growing economy, you should care about child care. Millions are leaving the workforce, hesitating to form small businesses, or forgoing promotions because child care is unaffordable for most families. Our entire economy is hurt as a result. (THREAD)
